member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes
member.summary: Designates the console buffer mode on the and functions

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_PROCESSED_INPUT
member.summary: CTRL+C is processed by the system and is not placed in the input buffer. If the input buffer is being read by or , other control keys are processed by the system and are not returned in the or buffer. If the mode is also enabled, backspace, carriage return, and line feed characters are handled by the system.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_PROCESSED_OUTPUT
member.summary: Characters written by the or function or echoed by the or function are parsed for ASCII control sequences, and the correct action is performed. Backspace, tab, bell, carriage return, and line feed characters are processed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_LINE_INPUT
member.summary: The or function returns only when a carriage return character is read. If this mode is disabled, the functions return when one or more characters are available.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_WRAP_AT_EOL_OUTPUT
member.summary: When writing with or or echoing with or , the cursor moves to the beginning of the next row when it reaches the end of the current row. This causes the rows displayed in the console window to scroll up automatically when the cursor advances beyond the last row in the window. It also causes the contents of the console screen buffer to scroll up (discarding the top row of the console screen buffer) when the cursor advances beyond the last row in the console screen buffer. If this mode is disabled, the last character in the row is overwritten with any subsequent characters.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_ECHO_INPUT
member.summary: Characters read by the or function are written to the active screen buffer as they are read. This mode can be used only if the mode is also enabled.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING
member.summary: When writing with or , characters are parsed for VT100 and similar control character sequences that control cursor movement, color/font mode, and other operations that can also be performed via the existing Console APIs.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_WINDOW_INPUT
member.summary: User interactions that change the size of the console screen buffer are reported in the console's input buffer. Information about these events can be read from the input buffer by applications using the function, but not by those using or .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.DISABLE_NEWLINE_AUTO_RETURN
member.summary: When writing with or , this adds an additional state to end-of-line wrapping that can delay the cursor move and buffer scroll operations. Normally when is set and text reaches the end of the line, the cursor will immediately move to the next line and the contents of the buffer will scroll up by one line. In contrast with this flag set, the scroll operation and cursor move is delayed until the next character arrives. The written character will be printed in the final position on the line and the cursor will remain above this character as if was off, but the next printable character will be printed as if ENABLE_WRAP_AT_EOL_OUTPUT is on. No overwrite will occur. Specifically, the cursor quickly advances down to the following line, a scroll is performed if necessary, the character is printed, and the cursor advances one more position. The typical usage of this flag is intended in conjunction with setting ENABLE_VIRTUAL_TERMINAL_PROCESSING to better emulate a terminal emulator where writing the final character on the screen (in the bottom right corner) without triggering an immediate scroll is the desired behavior.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_MOUSE_INPUT
member.summary: If the mouse pointer is within the borders of the console window and the window has the keyboard focus, mouse events generated by mouse movement and button presses are placed in the input buffer. These events are discarded by or , even when this mode is enabled.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_LVB_GRID_WORLDWIDE
member.summary: The APIs for writing character attributes including and WriteConsoleOutputAttribute allow the usage of flags from character attributes to adjust the color of the foreground and background of text. Additionally, a range of DBCS flags was specified with the COMMON_LVB prefix. Historically, these flags only functioned in DBCS code pages for Chinese, Japanese, and Korean languages. With exception of the leading byte and trailing byte flags, the remaining flags describing line drawing and reverse video (swap foreground and background colors) can be useful for other languages to emphasize portions of output. Setting this console mode flag will allow these attributes to be used in every code page on every language. It is off by default to maintain compatibility with known applications that have historically taken advantage of the console ignoring these flags on non-CJK machines to store bits in these fields for their own purposes or by accident. Note that using the mode can result in LVB grid and reverse video flags being set while this flag is still off if the attached application requests underlining or inverse video via Console Virtual Terminal Sequences.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_INSERT_MODE
member.summary: When enabled, text entered in a console window will be inserted at the current cursor location and all text following that location will not be overwritten. When disabled, all following text will be overwritten.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ConsoleBufferModes.ENABLE_QUICK_EDIT_MODE
member.summary: This flag enables the user to use the mouse to select and edit text.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.ControlType
member.summary: Values that are passed to the callback.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ControlType.CTRL_C_EVENT
member.summary: A CTRL+C signal was received, either from keyboard input or from a signal generated by the function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ControlType.CTRL_BREAK_EVENT
member.summary: A CTRL+BREAK signal was received, either from keyboard input or from a signal generated by .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ControlType.CTRL_CLOSE_EVENT
member.summary: A signal that the system sends to all processes attached to a console when the user closes the console (either by clicking Close on the console window's window menu, or by clicking the End Task button command from Task Manager).

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ControlType.CTRL_LOGOFF_EVENT
member.summary: A signal that the system sends to all console processes when a user is logging off. This signal does not indicate which user is logging off, so no assumptions can be made.
member.remarks: Note that this signal is received only by services. Interactive applications are terminated at logoff, so they are not present when the system sends this signal.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ControlType.CTRL_SHUTDOWN_EVENT
member.summary: A signal that the system sends when the system is shutting down. Interactive applications are not present by the time the system sends this signal, therefore it can be received only be services in this situation. Services also have their own notification mechanism for shutdown events. For more information, see .
member.remarks: This signal can also be generated by an application using GenerateConsoleCtrlEvent.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags
member.summary: Flags that may be passed to the function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.None
member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_BREAKAWAY_FROM_JOB
member.summary: The child processes of a process associated with a job are not associated with the job. If the calling process is not associated with a job, this constant has no effect. If the calling process is associated with a job, the job must set the JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_BREAKAWAY_OK limit.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_DEFAULT_ERROR_MODE
member.summary: The new process does not inherit the error mode of the calling process. Instead, the new process gets the default error mode. This feature is particularly useful for multithreaded shell applications that run with hard errors disabled. The default behavior is for the new process to inherit the error mode of the caller. Setting this flag changes that default behavior.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_NEW_CONSOLE
member.summary: The new process has a new console, instead of inheriting its parent's console (the default). For more information, see Creation of a Console. This flag cannot be used with DETACHED_PROCESS.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_NEW_PROCESS_GROUP
member.summary: The new process is the root process of a new process group. The process group includes all processes that are descendants of this root process. The process identifier of the new process group is the same as the process identifier, which is returned in the lpProcessInformation parameter. Process groups are used by the GenerateConsoleCtrlEvent function to enable sending a CTRL+BREAK signal to a group of console processes. If this flag is specified, CTRL+C signals will be disabled for all processes within the new process group. This flag is ignored if specified with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_NO_WINDOW
member.summary: The process is a console application that is being run without a console window. Therefore, the console handle for the application is not set. This flag is ignored if the application is not a console application, or if it is used with either or .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_PROTECTED_PROCESS
member.summary: The process is to be run as a protected process. The system restricts access to protected processes and the threads of protected processes. For more information on how processes can interact with protected processes, see Process Security and Access Rights. To activate a protected process, the binary must have a special signature. This signature is provided by Microsoft but not currently available for non-Microsoft binaries. There are currently four protected processes: media foundation, audio engine, Windows error reporting, and system. Components that load into these binaries must also be signed. Multimedia companies can leverage the first two protected processes. For more information, see Overview of the Protected Media Path. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_PRESERVE_CODE_AUTHZ_LEVEL
member.summary: Allows the caller to execute a child process that bypasses the process restrictions that would normally be applied automatically to the process.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_SEPARATE_WOW_VDM
member.summary: This flag is valid only when starting a 16-bit Windows-based application. If set, the new process runs in a private Virtual DOS Machine (VDM). By default, all 16-bit Windows-based applications run as threads in a single, shared VDM. The advantage of running separately is that a crash only terminates the single VDM; any other programs running in distinct VDMs continue to function normally. Also, 16-bit Windows-based applications that are run in separate VDMs have separate input queues. That means that if one application stops responding momentarily, applications in separate VDMs continue to receive input. The disadvantage of running separately is that it takes significantly more memory to do so. You should use this flag only if the user requests that 16-bit applications should run in their own VDM.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_SHARED_WOW_VDM
member.summary: The flag is valid only when starting a 16-bit Windows-based application. If the DefaultSeparateVDM switch in the Windows section of WIN.INI is TRUE, this flag overrides the switch. The new process is run in the shared Virtual DOS Machine.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_SUSPENDED
member.summary: The primary thread of the new process is created in a suspended state, and does not run until the function is called.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.CREATE_UNICODE_ENVIRONMENT
member.summary: If this flag is set, the environment block pointed to by lpEnvironment uses Unicode characters. Otherwise, the environment block uses ANSI characters.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.DEBUG_ONLY_THIS_PROCESS
member.summary: The calling thread starts and debugs the new process. It can receive all related debug events using the WaitForDebugEvent function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.DEBUG_PROCESS
member.summary: The calling thread starts and debugs the new process and all child processes created by the new process. It can receive all related debug events using the WaitForDebugEvent function. A process that uses becomes the root of a debugging chain. This continues until another process in the chain is created with . If this flag is combined with , the caller debugs only the new process, not any child processes.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.DETACHED_PROCESS
member.summary: For console processes, the new process does not inherit its parent's console (the default). The new process can call the function at a later time to create a console. For more information, see Creation of a Console. This value cannot be used with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.EXTENDED_STARTUPINFO_PRESENT
member.summary: The process is created with extended startup information; the lpStartupInfo parameter specifies a structure. Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateProcessFlags.INHERIT_PARENT_AFFINITY
member.summary: The process inherits its parent's affinity. If the parent process has threads in more than one processor group, the new process inherits the group-relative affinity of an arbitrary group in use by the parent. Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags
member.summary: The portions of the system to be included in the snapshot for .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_INHERIT
member.summary: Indicates that the snapshot handle is to be inheritable.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_SNAPHEAPLIST
member.summary: Includes all heaps of the process specified in th32ProcessID in the snapshot. To enumerate the heaps, see Heap32ListFirst.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_SNAPMODULE
member.summary:
Includes all modules of the process specified in th32ProcessID in the snapshot. To enumerate the modules, see . If the function fails with , retry the function until it succeeds.
64-bit Windows: Using this flag in a 32-bit process includes the 32-bit modules of the process specified in th32ProcessID, while using it in a 64-bit process includes the 64-bit modules. To include the 32-bit modules of the process specified in th32ProcessID from a 64-bit process, use the flag.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_SNAPMODULE32
member.summary: Includes all 32-bit modules of the process specified in th32ProcessID in the snapshot when called from a 64-bit process. This flag can be combined with or . If the function fails with , retry the function until it succeeds.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_SNAPPROCESS
member.summary: Includes all processes in the system in the snapshot. To enumerate the processes, see .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_SNAPTHREAD
member.summary:
Includes all threads in the system in the snapshot. To enumerate the threads, see Thread32First.
To identify the threads that belong to a specific process, compare its process identifier to the th32OwnerProcessID member of the THREADENTRY32 structure when enumerating the threads.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.CreateToolhelp32SnapshotFlags.TH32CS_SNAPALL
member.summary: Includes all processes and threads in the system, plus the heaps and modules of the process specified in th32ProcessID.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.EXECUTION_STATE.ES_CONTINUOUS

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GetModuleHandleExFlags.GET_MODULE_HANDLE_EX_FLAG_PIN
member.summary: The module stays loaded until the process is terminated, no matter how many times is called.
member.remarks: This option cannot be used with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GetModuleHandleExFlags.GET_MODULE_HANDLE_EX_FLAG_UNCHANGED_REFCOUNT
member.summary: The reference count for the module is not incremented. This option is equivalent to the behavior of . Do not pass the retrieved module handle to the function; doing so can cause the DLL to be unmapped prematurely.
member.remarks: This option cannot be used with .

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags
member.summary: Flags for the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_FIXED
member.summary: Allocates fixed memory. The return value is a pointer.
member.remarks: Cannot be combined with the flags.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_MOVEABLE
member.summary: Allocates movable memory. Memory blocks are never moved in physical memory, but they can be moved within the default heap. The return value is a handle to the memory object. To translate the handle into a pointer, use the function.
member.remarks: This value cannot be combined with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_NOCOMPACT
member.summary: Does not compact or discard memory to satisfy the allocation request.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_NODISCARD
member.summary: Does not discard memory to satisfy the allocation request.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_ZEROINIT
member.summary: Initializes memory contents to zero

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GPTR
member.summary: Combines and

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GHND
member.summary: Combines and

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_DISCARDABLE
member.summary: Allocates discardable memory.
member.remarks: This flag can only be used with the GMEM_MOVEABLE flag.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_NOT_BANKED
member.summary: Allocates non-banked memory (memory is not within the flag). Same as .
member.remarks: This flag is ignored in Windows 3.1.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_LOWER
member.summary: Allocates non-banked memory (memory is not within the flag). Same as .
member.remarks: This flag is ignored in Windows 3.1.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_DDESHARE
member.summary: Allocates memory that can be shared with other applications. This flag is used for dynamic data exchange (DDE) only.
member.remarks: This flag is equivalent to .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_SHARE
member.summary: Allocates memory that can be shared with other applications. This flag is used for dynamic data exchange (DDE) only.
member.remarks: This flag is equivalent to .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalAllocFlags.GMEM_NOTIFY
member.summary: Calls the notification routine if the memory object is discarded.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalReAllocFlags
member.summary: Flags for the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalReAllocFlags.GMEM_MODIFY
member.summary: Modifies the attributes of the memory object only (the uBytes parameter is ignored.) Otherwise, the function reallocates the memory object.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalReAllocFlags.GMEM_MOVEABLE
member.summary: Allocates fixed or movable memory. If the memory is a locked memory block or a memory block and this flag is not specified, the memory can only be reallocated in place.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.GlobalReAllocFlags.GMEM_ZEROINIT
member.summary: Causes the additional memory contents to be initialized to zero if the memory object is growing in size.
member.remarks: If the parameter does not specify , you can use this value.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapAllocFlags
member.summary: Flags for the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapAllocFlags.HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS
member.summary: The system will raise an exception to indicate a function failure, such as an out-of-memory condition, instead of returning NULL.
member.remarks: To ensure that exceptions are generated for all calls to this function, specify HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS in the call to HeapCreate. In this case, it is not necessary to additionally specify HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS in this function call.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapAllocFlags.HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE
member.summary: Serialized access will not be used for this allocation.

remarks.para: To ensure that serialized access is disabled for all calls to this function, specify HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE in the call to HeapCreate. In this case, it is not necessary to additionally specify HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE in this function call.

This value should not be specified when accessing the process's default heap. The system may create additional threads within the application's process, such as a CTRL+C handler, that simultaneously access the process's default heap.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapAllocFlags.HEAP_ZERO_MEMORY
member.summary: The allocated memory will be initialized to zero. Otherwise, the memory is not initialized to zero.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapFreeFlags
member.summary: Flags for the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapFreeFlags.HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE
member.summary: Serialized access will not be used.

remarks.para: To ensure that serialized access is disabled for all calls to this function, specify HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE in the call to HeapCreate. In this case, it is not necessary to additionally specify HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE in this function call.

Do not specify this value when accessing the process heap. The system may create additional threads within the application's process, such as a CTRL+C handler, that simultaneously access the process heap.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapReAllocFlags
member.summary: Flags for the method.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapReAllocFlags.HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS
member.summary: The operating-system raises an exception to indicate a function failure, such as an out-of-memory condition, instead of returning NULL.
member.remarks: To ensure that exceptions are generated for all calls to this function, specify HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS in the call to HeapCreate. In this case, it is not necessary to additionally specify HEAP_GENERATE_EXCEPTIONS in this function call.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapReAllocFlags.HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE
member.summary: Serialized access will not be used.

remarks.para: To ensure that serialized access is disabled for all calls to this function, specify HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE in the call to HeapCreate. In this case, it is not necessary to additionally specify HEAP_NO_SERIALIZE in this function call.

This value should not be specified when accessing the process's default heap. The system may create additional threads within the application's process, such as a CTRL+C handler, that simultaneously access the process's default heap.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapReAllocFlags.HEAP_REALLOC_IN_PLACE_ONLY
member.summary: There can be no movement when reallocating a memory block. If this value is not specified, the function may move the block to a new location. If this value is specified and the block cannot be resized without moving, the function fails, leaving the original memory block unchanged.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.HeapReAllocFlags.HEAP_ZERO_MEMORY
member.summary: If the reallocation request is for a larger size, the additional region of memory beyond the original size be initialized to zero. The contents of the memory block up to its original size are unaffected.

member.remarks: Taken from https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/windows/desktop/ms686216(v=vs.85).aspx

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectBasicLimitInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectBasicUIRestrictions
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_BASIC_UI_RESTRICTIONS structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectSecurityLimitInformation
member.summary: This flag is not supported. Applications must set security limitations individually for each process.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectEndOfJobTimeInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_END_OF_JOB_TIME_INFORMATION structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectAssociateCompletionPortInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_ASSOCIATE_COMPLETION_PORT structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectExtendedLimitInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectGroupInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a USHORT value that specifies the list of processor groups to assign the job to. The cbJobObjectInfoLength parameter is set to the size of the group data. Divide this value by sizeof(USHORT) to determine the number of groups.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectNotificationLimitInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_NOTIFICATION_LIMIT_INFORMATION structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectGroupInformationEx
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a buffer that contains an array of GROUP_AFFINITY structures that specify the affinity of the job for the processor groups to which the job is currently assigned. The cbJobObjectInfoLength parameter is set to the size of the group affinity data. Divide this value by sizeof(GROUP_AFFINITY) to determine the number of groups.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectCpuRateControlInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectNetRateControlInformation
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_NET_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectNotificationLimitInformation2
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_NOTIFICATION_LIMIT_INFORMATION_2 structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECTINFOCLASS.JobObjectLimitViolationInformation2
member.summary: The lpJobObjectInfo parameter is a pointer to a JOBOBJECT_LIMIT_VIOLATION_INFORMATION_2 structure.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION
member.summary: Contains basic limit information for a job object.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.PerProcessUserTimeLimit
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PROCESS_TIME, this member is the per-process user-mode execution time limit, in 100-nanosecond ticks. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.PerJobUserTimeLimit
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_JOB_TIME, this member is the per-job user-mode execution time limit, in 100-nanosecond ticks. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.LimitFlags
member.summary: The limit flags that are in effect. This member is a bitfield that determines whether other structure members are used.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.MinWorkingSetSize
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_WORKINGSET, this member is the minimum working set size in bytes for each process associated with the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.MaxWorkingSetSize
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_WORKINGSET, this member is the maximum working set size in bytes for each process associated with the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.ActiveProcessLimit
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_ACTIVE_PROCESS, this member is the active process limit for the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.Affinity
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_AFFINITY, this member is the processor affinity for all processes associated with the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.PriorityClass
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PRIORITY_CLASS, this member is the priority class for all processes associated with the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_BASIC_LIMIT_INFORMATION.SchedulingClass
member.summary: If LimitFlags specifies JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_SCHEDULING_CLASS, this member is the scheduling class for all processes associated with the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_FLAGS
member.summary: The scheduling policy for CPU rate control.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_ENABLE
member.summary: This flag enables the job's CPU rate to be controlled based on weight or hard cap. You must set this value if you also set JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_WEIGHT_BASED, JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_HARD_CAP, or JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_MIN_MAX_RATE.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_WEIGHT_BASED
member.summary: The job's CPU rate is calculated based on its relative weight to the weight of other jobs. If this flag is set, the Weight member contains more information. If this flag is clear, the CpuRate member contains more information.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_HARD_CAP
member.summary: The job's CPU rate is a hard limit. After the job reaches its CPU cycle limit for the current scheduling interval, no threads associated with the job will run until the next interval.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_NOTIFY
member.summary: Sends messages when the CPU rate for the job exceeds the rate limits for the job during the tolerance interval.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_MIN_MAX_RATE
member.summary: The CPU rate for the job is limited by minimum and maximum rates that you specify in the MinRate and MaxRate members.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION
member.summary: Contains CPU rate control information for a job object. This structure is used by the SetInformationJobObject and QueryInformationJobObject functions with the JobObjectCpuRateControlInformation information class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION.ControlFlags
member.summary: The scheduling policy for CPU rate control.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION.CpuRate
member.summary: Specifies the portion of processor cycles that the threads in a job object can use during each scheduling interval, as the number of cycles per 10,000 cycles. If the ControlFlags member specifies JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_WEIGHT_BASED or JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_MIN_MAX_RATE, this member is not used.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION.Weight
member.summary: If the ControlFlags member specifies JOB_OBJECT_CPU_RATE_WEIGHT_BASED, this member specifies the scheduling weight of the job object, which determines the share of processor time given to the job relative to other workloads on the processor.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION.MinRate
member.summary: Specifies the minimum portion of the processor cycles that the threads in a job object can reserve during each scheduling interval. Specify this rate as a percentage times 100. For example, to set a minimum rate of 50%, specify 50 times 100, or 5,000.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_CPU_RATE_CONTROL_INFORMATION.MaxRate
member.summary: Specifies the maximum portion of processor cycles that the threads in a job object can use during each scheduling interval. Specify this rate as a percentage times 100. For example, to set a maximum rate of 50%, specify 50 times 100, or 5,000.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION
member.summary: Contains basic and extended limit information for a job object.

remarks.para: The system tracks the value of PeakProcessMemoryUsed and PeakJobMemoryUsed constantly. This allows you know the peak memory usage of each job. You can use this information to establish a memory limit using the JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PROCESS_MEMORY or JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_JOB_MEMORY value.

Note that the job memory and process memory limits are very similar in operation, but they are independent. You could set a job-wide limit of 100 MB with a per-process limit of 10 MB. In this scenario, no single process could commit more than 10 MB, and the set of processes associated with a job could never exceed 100 MB.

To register for notifications that a job has exceeded its peak memory limit while allowing processes to continue to commit memory, use the SetInformationJobObject function with the JobObjectNotificationLimitInformation information class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION.BasicLimitInformation
member.summary: A structure that contains basic limit information.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION.IoInfo
member.summary: Reserved.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION.ProcessMemoryLimit
member.summary: If the member of the structure specifies the value, this member specifies the limit for the virtual memory that can be committed by a process. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION.JobMemoryLimit
member.summary: If the member of the structure specifies the value, this member specifies the limit for the virtual memory that can be committed for the job. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION.PeakProcessMemoryUsed
member.summary: The peak memory used by any process ever associated with the job.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOBOBJECT_EXTENDED_LIMIT_INFORMATION.PeakJobMemoryUsed
member.summary: The peak memory usage of all processes currently associated with the job.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS
member.summary: The limit flags that are in effect

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_WORKINGSET
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to use the same minimum and maximum working set sizes.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PROCESS_TIME
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to use the same priority class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_JOB_TIME
member.summary: Establishes a user-mode execution time limit for the job.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_ACTIVE_PROCESS
member.summary: Establishes a maximum number of simultaneously active processes associated with the job.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_AFFINITY
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to use the same processor affinity.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PRIORITY_CLASS
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to use the same priority class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PRESERVE_JOB_TIME
member.summary: Preserves any job time limits you previously set. As long as this flag is set, you can establish a per-job time limit once, then alter other limits in subsequent calls.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_SCHEDULING_CLASS
member.summary: Causes all processes in the job to use the same scheduling class.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_PROCESS_MEMORY
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to limit their committed memory.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_JOB_MEMORY
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to limit the job-wide sum of their committed memory.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_DIE_ON_UNHANDLED_EXCEPTION
member.summary: Forces a call to the SetErrorMode function with the SEM_NOGPFAULTERRORBOX flag for each process associated with the job.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_BREAKAWAY_OK
member.summary: If any process associated with the job creates a child process using the CREATE_BREAKAWAY_FROM_JOB flag while this limit is in effect, the child process is not associated with the job.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_SILENT_BREAKAWAY_OK
member.summary: Allows any process associated with the job to create child processes that are not associated with the job.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_KILL_ON_JOB_CLOSE
member.summary: Causes all processes associated with the job to terminate when the last handle to the job is closed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_FLAGS.JOB_OBJECT_LIMIT_SUBSET_AFFINITY
member.summary: Allows processes to use a subset of the processor affinity for all processes associated with the job.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD
member.summary: Describes a keyboard input event in a console structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD.bKeyDown
member.summary: If the key is pressed, this member is TRUE. Otherwise, this member is FALSE (the key is released).

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD.wRepeatCount
member.summary: The repeat count, which indicates that a key is being held down. For example, when a key is held down, you might get five events with this member equal to 1, one event with this member equal to 5, or multiple events with this member greater than or equal to 1.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD.wVirtualKeyCode
member.summary: A virtual-key code that identifies the given key in a device-independent manner. Possible values are in the User32.VirtualKey enum.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD.wVirtualScanCode
member.summary: The virtual scan code of the given key that represents the device-dependent value generated by the keyboard hardware. Possible values are in the User32.ScanCode enum.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD.uChar
member.summary: A union of the Unicode and Ascii encodings.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.KEY_EVENT_RECORD.dwControlKeyState
member.summary: The state of the control keys.

member.name: M:PInvoke.Kernel32.MAKELANGID(System.UInt16,System.UInt16)
member.summary: Creates a language identifier from a primary language identifier and a sublanguage identifier.
member.param: Primary language identifier. This identifier can be a predefined value or a value for a user-defined primary language. For a user-defined language, the identifier is a value in the range 0x0200 to 0x03FF. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.

Sublanguage identifier. This parameter can be a predefined sublanguage identifier or a user-defined sublanguage. For a user-defined sublanguage, the identifier is a value in the range 0x20 to 0x3F. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.
member.returns: Returns the language identifier.

member.name: M:PInvoke.Kernel32.MAKELANGID(PInvoke.Kernel32.LANGID.PrimaryLanguage,PInvoke.Kernel32.LANGID.SubLanguage)
member.summary: Creates a language identifier from a primary language identifier and a sublanguage identifier.
member.param: Primary language identifier. This identifier can be a predefined value or a value for a user-defined primary language. For a user-defined language, the identifier is a value in the range 0x0200 to 0x03FF. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.

Sublanguage identifier. This parameter can be a predefined sublanguage identifier or a user-defined sublanguage. For a user-defined sublanguage, the identifier is a value in the range 0x20 to 0x3F. All other values are reserved for operating system use. For more information, see Language Identifier Constants and Strings.
member.returns: Returns the language identifier.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.LANGID
member.summary: Represents a language identifier.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags
member.summary: Flags that may be passed to the function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.None
member.summary: Define no flags, the function will behave as does.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.DONT_RESOLVE_DLL_REFERENCES
member.summary: If this value is used, and the executable module is a DLL, the system does not call DllMain for process and thread initialization and termination. Also, the system does not load additional executable modules that are referenced by the specified module.
member.remarks: Do not use this value; it is provided only for backward compatibility. If you are planning to access only data or resources in the DLL, use or or both. Otherwise, load the library as a DLL or executable module using the LoadLibrary function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_IGNORE_CODE_AUTHZ_LEVEL
member.summary: If this value is used, the system does not check AppLocker rules or apply Software Restriction Policies for the DLL. This action applies only to the DLL being loaded and not to its dependencies. This value is recommended for use in setup programs that must run extracted DLLs during installation.

remarks.para: Windows Server 2008 R2 and Windows 7: On systems with KB2532445 installed, the caller must be running as "LocalSystem" or "TrustedInstaller"; otherwise the system ignores this flag. For more information, see "You can circumvent AppLocker rules by using an Office macro on a computer that is running Windows 7 or Windows Server 2008 R2" in the Help and Support Knowledge Base at http://support.microsoft.com/kb/2532445.
Windows Server 2008, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2003, and Windows XP: AppLocker was introduced in Windows 7 and Windows Server 2008 R2.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE
member.summary:
If this value is used, the system maps the file into the calling process's virtual address space as if it were a data file. Nothing is done to execute or prepare to execute the mapped file. Therefore, you cannot call functions like GetModuleFileName, GetModuleHandle or GetProcAddress with this DLL. Using this value causes writes to read-only memory to raise an access violation. Use this flag when you want to load a DLL only to extract messages or resources from it.
This value can be used with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_DATAFILE_EXCLUSIVE
member.summary:
Similar to , except that the DLL file is opened with exclusive write access for the calling process. Other processes cannot open the DLL file for write access while it is in use. However, the DLL can still be opened by other processes.
This value can be used with .
member.remarks: Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported until Windows Vista.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_AS_IMAGE_RESOURCE
member.summary:
If this value is used, the system maps the file into the process's virtual address space as an image file. However, the loader does not load the static imports or perform the other usual initialization steps. Use this flag when you want to load a DLL only to extract messages or resources from it.
Unless the application depends on the file having the in-memory layout of an image, this value should be used with either or . For more information, see the Remarks section.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_APPLICATION_DIR
member.summary: If this value is used, the application's installation directory is searched for the DLL and its dependencies. Directories in the standard search path are not searched. This value cannot be combined with .
member.remarks:
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_DEFAULT_DIRS
member.summary:
This value is a combination of , , and . Directories in the standard search path are not searched. This value cannot be combined with .
This value represents the recommended maximum number of directories an application should include in its DLL search path.
member.remarks:
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_DLL_LOAD_DIR
member.summary:
If this value is used, the directory that contains the DLL is temporarily added to the beginning of the list of directories that are searched for the DLL's dependencies. Directories in the standard search path are not searched.
The lpFileName parameter must specify a fully qualified path. This value cannot be combined with .
For example, if Lib2.dll is a dependency of C:\Dir1\Lib1.dll, loading Lib1.dll with this value causes the system to search for Lib2.dll only in C:\Dir1. To search for Lib2.dll in C:\Dir1 and all of the directories in the DLL search path, combine this value with .
member.remarks:
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_SYSTEM32
member.summary: If this value is used, %windows%\system32 is searched for the DLL and its dependencies. Directories in the standard search path are not searched. This value cannot be combined with .
member.remarks:
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH_USER_DIRS
member.summary: If this value is used, directories added using the AddDllDirectory or the SetDllDirectory function are searched for the DLL and its dependencies. If more than one directory has been added, the order in which the directories are searched is unspecified. Directories in the standard search path are not searched. This value cannot be combined with .
member.remarks:
Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, and Windows Server 2008: This value requires KB2533623 to be installed.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP: This value is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LoadLibraryExFlags.LOAD_WITH_ALTERED_SEARCH_PATH
member.summary:
If this value is used and lpFileName specifies an absolute path, the system uses the alternate file search strategy discussed in the Remarks section to find associated executable modules that the specified module causes to be loaded. If this value is used and lpFileName specifies a relative path, the behavior is undefined.
If this value is not used, or if lpFileName does not specify a path, the system uses the standard search strategy discussed in the Remarks section to find associated executable modules that the specified module causes to be loaded.
This value cannot be combined with any LOAD_LIBRARY_SEARCH flag.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.LocalAllocFlags

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LocalAllocFlags.LMEM_FIXED
member.summary: Allocates fixed memory. The return value is a pointer to the memory object.

member.summary: Combines LMEM_MOVEABLE and LMEM_ZEROINIT

member.summary: Allocates movable memory. Memory blocks are never moved in physical memory, but they can be moved within the default heap. The return value is a handle to the memory object. To translate the handle to a pointer, use the LocalLock function. This value cannot be combined with .

member.summary: Initializes memory contents to zero.

member.summary: Combines and .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LocalReAllocFlags.LMEM_MODIFY
member.summary: modifies the attributes of the memory object only (the uBytes parameter is ignored.) Otherwise, the function reallocates the memory object.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LocalReAllocFlags.LMEM_MOVEABLE
member.summary: Allocates fixed or movable memory. If the memory is a locked memory block or a memory block and this flag is not specified, the memory can only be reallocated in place.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.LocalReAllocFlags.LMEM_ZEROINIT
member.summary: Causes the additional memory contents to be initialized to zero if the memory object is growing in size.
member.remarks: If the parameter does not specify , you can use this value.

member.summary: The horizontal mouse wheel was moved. If the high word of the member contains a positive value, the wheel was rotated to the right. Otherwise, the wheel was rotated to the left.

member.summary: A change in mouse position occurred.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.NamedPipeInfoFlags
member.summary: Flags returned by .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.NamedPipeInfoFlags.PIPE_CLIENT_END
member.summary: The handle refers to the client end of a named pipe instance. This is the default.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.NamedPipeInfoFlags.PIPE_SERVER_END
member.summary: The handle refers to the server end of a named pipe instance. If this value is not specified, the handle refers to the client end of a named pipe instance.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.NamedPipeInfoFlags.PIPE_TYPE_BYTE
member.summary: The named pipe is a byte pipe. This is the default.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.NamedPipeInfoFlags.PIPE_TYPE_MESSAGE
member.summary: The named pipe is a message pipe. If this value is not specified, the pipe is a byte pipe.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode
member.summary: Pipe access mode used when creating a pipe using .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.PIPE_ACCESS_DUPLEX
member.summary: The pipe is bi-directional; both server and client processes can read from and write to the pipe. This mode gives the server the equivalent of GENERIC_READ and GENERIC_WRITE access to the pipe. The client can specify GENERIC_READ or GENERIC_WRITE, or both, when it connects to the pipe using the CreateFile function.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.PIPE_ACCESS_INBOUND
member.summary: The flow of data in the pipe goes from client to server only. This mode gives the server the equivalent of GENERIC_READ access to the pipe. The client must specify GENERIC_WRITE access when connecting to the pipe. If the client must read pipe settings by calling the GetNamedPipeInfo or GetNamedPipeHandleState functions, the client must specify GENERIC_WRITE and FILE_READ_ATTRIBUTES access when connecting to the pipe.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.PIPE_ACCESS_OUTBOUND
member.summary: The flow of data in the pipe goes from server to client only. This mode gives the server the equivalent of GENERIC_WRITE access to the pipe. The client must specify GENERIC_READ access when connecting to the pipe. If the client must change pipe settings by calling the SetNamedPipeHandleState function, the client must specify GENERIC_READ and FILE_WRITE_ATTRIBUTES access when connecting to the pipe.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.FILE_FLAG_FIRST_PIPE_INSTANCE
member.summary:
If you attempt to create multiple instances of a pipe with this flag, creation of the first instance succeeds, but creation of the next instance fails with ERROR_ACCESS_DENIED.
Windows 2000: This flag is not supported until Windows 2000 SP2 and Windows XP.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.FILE_FLAG_WRITE_THROUGH
member.summary: Write-through mode is enabled. This mode affects only write operations on byte-type pipes and, then, only when the client and server processes are on different computers. If this mode is enabled, functions writing to a named pipe do not return until the data written is transmitted across the network and is in the pipe's buffer on the remote computer. If this mode is not enabled, the system enhances the efficiency of network operations by buffering data until a minimum number of bytes accumulate or until a maximum time elapses.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.FILE_FLAG_OVERLAPPED
member.summary: Overlapped mode is enabled. If this mode is enabled, functions performing read, write, and connect operations that may take a significant time to be completed can return immediately. This mode enables the thread that started the operation to perform other operations while the time-consuming operation executes in the background. For example, in overlapped mode, a thread can handle simultaneous input and output (I/O) operations on multiple instances of a pipe or perform simultaneous read and write operations on the same pipe handle. If overlapped mode is not enabled, functions performing read, write, and connect operations on the pipe handle do not return until the operation is finished. The ReadFileEx and WriteFileEx functions can only be used with a pipe handle in overlapped mode. The ReadFile, WriteFile, ConnectNamedPipe, and TransactNamedPipe functions can execute either synchronously or as overlapped operations.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.WRITE_DAC
member.summary: The caller will have write access to the named pipe's discretionary access control list (ACL).

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.WRITE_OWNER
member.summary: The caller will have write access to the named pipe's owner.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeAccessMode.ACCESS_SYSTEM_SECURITY
member.summary: The caller will have write access to the named pipe's SACL.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode
member.summary: A named pipe usage mode, used in .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_TYPE_BYTE
member.summary: Data is written to the pipe as a stream of bytes. This mode cannot be used with . The pipe does not distinguish bytes written during different write operations.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_TYPE_MESSAGE
member.summary: Data is written to the pipe as a stream of messages. The pipe treats the bytes written during each write operation as a message unit. The GetLastError function returns when a message is not read completely. This mode can be used with either or .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_READMODE_BYTE
member.summary: Data is read from the pipe as a stream of bytes. This mode can be used with either or .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_READMODE_MESSAGE
member.summary: Data is read from the pipe as a stream of messages. This mode can be only used if is also specified.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_WAIT
member.summary: Blocking mode is enabled. When the pipe handle is specified in the , , or function, the operations are not completed until there is data to read, all data is written, or a client is connected. Use of this mode can mean waiting indefinitely in some situations for a client process to perform an action.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_NOWAIT
member.summary:
Nonblocking mode is enabled. In this mode, , , and ConnectNamedPipe always return immediately.
Note that nonblocking mode is supported for compatibility with Microsoft LAN Manager version 2.0 and should not be used to achieve asynchronous I/O with named pipes.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_ACCEPT_REMOTE_CLIENTS
member.summary:
Connections from remote clients can be accepted and checked against the security descriptor for the pipe.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP/2000: This flag is not supported.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PipeMode.PIPE_REJECT_REMOTE_CLIENTS
member.summary:
Connections from remote clients are automatically rejected.
Windows Server 2003 and Windows XP/2000: This flag is not supported. To achieve the same results, deny access to the pipe to the NETWORK ACE.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.ProcessAccess.PROCESS_VM_WRITE

The name of the executable file for the process.
To retrieve the full path to the executable file, call the Module32First function and check the szExePath member of the MODULEENTRY32 structure that is returned. However, if the calling process is a 32-bit process, you must call the

function to retrieve the full path of the executable file for a 64-bit process.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PROCESS_INFORMATION.dwProcessId
member.summary: A value that can be used to identify a process. The value is valid from the time the process is created until all handles to the process are closed and the process object is freed; at this point, the identifier may be reused.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.PROCESS_INFORMATION.dwThreadId
member.summary: A value that can be used to identify a thread. The value is valid from the time the thread is created until all handles to the thread are closed and the thread object is freed; at this point, the identifier may be reused.

member.name: T:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO
member.summary: Specifies the window station, desktop, standard handles, and appearance of the main window for a process at creation time.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.cb
member.summary: The size of this data structure.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.lpReserved
member.summary: Reserved; must be NULL.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.lpDesktop
member.summary: The name of the desktop, or the name of both the desktop and window station for this process. A backslash in the string indicates that the string includes both the desktop and window station names. For more information, see Thread Connection to a Desktop.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.lpTitle
member.summary: For console processes, this is the title displayed in the title bar if a new console window is created. If NULL, the name of the executable file is used as the window title instead. This parameter must be NULL for GUI or console processes that do not create a new console window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwX
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USEPOSITION, this member is the x offset of the upper left corner of a window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored. The offset is from the upper left corner of the screen. For GUI processes, the specified position is used the first time the new process calls CreateWindow to create an overlapped window if the x parameter of CreateWindow is CW_USEDEFAULT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwY
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USEPOSITION, this member is the y offset of the upper left corner of a window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored. The offset is from the upper left corner of the screen. For GUI processes, the specified position is used the first time the new process calls CreateWindow to create an overlapped window if the y parameter of CreateWindow is CW_USEDEFAULT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwXSize
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USESIZE, this member is the width of the window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored. For GUI processes, this is used only the first time the new process calls CreateWindow to create an overlapped window if the nWidth parameter of CreateWindow is CW_USEDEFAULT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwYSize
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USESIZE, this member is the height of the window if a new window is created, in pixels. Otherwise, this member is ignored. For GUI processes, this is used only the first time the new process calls CreateWindow to create an overlapped window if the nHeight parameter of CreateWindow is CW_USEDEFAULT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwXCountChars
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USECOUNTCHARS, if a new console window is created in a console process, this member specifies the screen buffer width, in character columns. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwYCountChars
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USECOUNTCHARS, if a new console window is created in a console process, this member specifies the screen buffer height, in character rows. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwFillAttribute
member.summary: If specifies STARTF_USEFILLATTRIBUTE, this member is the initial text and background colors if a new console window is created in a console application. Otherwise, this member is ignored. This value can be any combination of the following values: FOREGROUND_BLUE, FOREGROUND_GREEN, FOREGROUND_RED, FOREGROUND_INTENSITY, BACKGROUND_BLUE, BACKGROUND_GREEN, BACKGROUND_RED, and BACKGROUND_INTENSITY. For example, the following combination of values produces red text on a white background: FOREGROUND_RED| BACKGROUND_RED| BACKGROUND_GREEN| BACKGROUND_BLUE

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.dwFlags
member.summary: A bitfield that determines whether certain STARTUPINFO members are used when the process creates a window.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.wShowWindow
member.summary: If specifies , this member can be any of the values that can be specified in the nCmdShow parameter for the ShowWindow function, except for SW_SHOWDEFAULT. Otherwise, this member is ignored. For GUI processes, the first time ShowWindow is called, its nCmdShow parameter is ignored wShowWindow specifies the default value. In subsequent calls to ShowWindow, the wShowWindow member is used if the nCmdShow parameter of ShowWindow is set to SW_SHOWDEFAULT.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.cbReserved2
member.summary: Reserved for use by the C Run-time; must be zero.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.lpReserved2
member.summary: Reserved for use by the C Run-time; must be NULL.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.hStdInput
member.summary: If specifies , this member is the standard input handle for the process. If is not specified, the default for standard input is the keyboard buffer. If specifies , this member specifies a hotkey value that is sent as the wParam parameter of a WM_SETHOTKEY message to the first eligible top-level window created by the application that owns the process. If the window is created with the WS_POPUP window style, it is not eligible unless the WS_EX_APPWINDOW extended window style is also set. For more information, see CreateWindowEx. Otherwise, this member is ignored.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.hStdOutput
member.summary: If specifies , this member is the standard output handle for the process. Otherwise, this member is ignored and the default for standard output is the console window's buffer. If a process is launched from the taskbar or jump list, the system sets to a handle to the monitor that contains the taskbar or jump list used to launch the process. For more information, see Remarks. Windows 7, Windows Server 2008 R2, Windows Vista, Windows Server 2008, Windows XP, and Windows Server 2003: This behavior was introduced in Windows 8 and Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.STARTUPINFO.hStdError
member.summary: If specifies , this member is the standard error handle for the process. Otherwise, this member is ignored and the default for standard error is the console window's buffer.

member.summary: No flags.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_FORCEONFEEDBACK
member.summary: Indicates that the cursor is in feedback mode for two seconds after is called. The Working in Background cursor is displayed (see the Pointers tab in the Mouse control panel utility). If during those two seconds the process makes the first GUI call, the system gives five more seconds to the process. If during those five seconds the process shows a window, the system gives five more seconds to the process to finish drawing the window. The system turns the feedback cursor off after the first call to GetMessage, regardless of whether the process is drawing.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_FORCEOFFFEEDBACK
member.summary: Indicates that the feedback cursor is forced off while the process is starting. The Normal Select cursor is displayed.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_PREVENTPINNING
member.summary: Indicates that any windows created by the process cannot be pinned on the taskbar. This flag must be combined with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_RUNFULLSCREEN
member.summary: Indicates that the process should be run in full-screen mode, rather than in windowed mode. This flag is only valid for console applications running on an x86 computer.

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_TITLEISAPPID
member.summary: The lpTitle member contains an AppUserModelID. This identifier controls how the taskbar and Start menu present the application, and enables it to be associated with the correct shortcuts and Jump Lists. Generally, applications will use the SetCurrentProcessExplicitAppUserModelID and GetCurrentProcessExplicitAppUserModelID functions instead of setting this flag. For more information, see Application User Model IDs. If is used, application windows cannot be pinned on the taskbar. The use of any AppUserModelID-related window properties by the application overrides this setting for that window only. This flag cannot be used with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_TITLEISLINKNAME
member.summary: The lpTitle member contains the path of the shortcut file (.lnk) that the user invoked to start this process. This is typically set by the shell when a .lnk file pointing to the launched application is invoked. Most applications will not need to set this value. This flag cannot be used with .

member.name: F:PInvoke.Kernel32.StartupInfoFlags.STARTF_UNTRUSTEDSOURCE
member.summary: The command line came from an untrusted source. For more information, see Remarks.

member.summary: The and members contain additional information.

member.summary: The , , and members contain additional information.
